title: 110_hr5425
content: The Act titled "Flexibility in Rebuilding American Fisheries Act of 2008" extends the time period for rebuilding certain overfished fisheries. Section 304(e) of the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act is amended to allow for a maximum rebuilding period of 10 years, with exceptions based on stock biology, environmental conditions, or international agreements. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act allows for a 10-year rebuilding period, which can be extended under certain circumstances such as when the cause of fishery decline is outside the Council's jurisdiction or to sustain fishing communities with evidence of positive fish stock rebuilding trends. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act allows for a 10-year rebuilding period, which can be extended under certain circumstances such as positive fish stock rebuilding trends or substantial changes to biomass targets. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act allows for a 10-year rebuilding period for fish stocks, which can be extended if the biomass rebuilding target exceeds historical abundance levels and there is evidence of a positive rebuilding trend. The Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act allows for a 10-year rebuilding period for fish stocks, which can be extended if necessary. The extension cannot exceed a certain time limit based on specific criteria. The Magnuson-Stevens Act allows for a 10-year rebuilding period for fish stocks, extendable based on specific criteria. "On a positive rebuilding trend" means a substantial increase in fish stock abundance since the rebuilding plan implementation.
